thread.title: Brett McLeod: Malcolm Turnbull's biggest problem is one he created for himself
thread.title_full: Brett McLeod: Malcolm Turnbull's biggest problem is one he created for himself

title: Brett McLeod: Malcolm Turnbull's biggest problem is one he created for himself
text:
Brett McLeod: Malcolm Turnbull's biggest problem is one he created for himself By Brett McLeod Brett McLeod: The prime minister used Newspoll results to justify his decision to overthrow Tony Abbott as leader in 2015 - which means the latest figures won't be so easy to sweep under the rug. 
Most politicians dismiss opinion polls with the mantra: "Polls come and go, but there’s only one poll that matters". 
Malcolm Turnbull was more explicit when he finally challenged for the Liberal leadership in late 2015: 30 Newspolls showed Tony Abbott had to go. 
But the benchmark you set is the one you will be judged by. 
Turnbull hasn’t lost 30 Newspolls in a row, he has lost eight. But today’s figures put the Coalition seriously underwater: ten points behind Labor. 
Two factors won’t have helped: One Nation and Tony Abbott. 
The ousted PM promised “no sniping” when he lost the leadership. Last week he set off a hand grenade instead. 
His five point plan got plenty of attention, reinvigorated tensions over the direction of the Liberal party and led to public comments by former colleagues showing Mr Abbott now as popular as a Polly Waffle in a swimming pool. 
The Abbott Agenda - no new debt, lower immigration, lower taxes etc - could be easily dismissed as a list of things he failed to achieve as leader. 
But it does tally with grievances from voters now drifting towards One Nation - particularly when it comes to immigration. Pauline Hanson’s party now has ten percent of the primary vote – double that of late last year. 
Their next electoral test is the WA state election. A strong result there will further embolden those on Mr Turnbull’s right. 
In the preferred Prime Minister horse race Turnbull continues to enjoy a lead over Bill Shorten. But personal popularity can be overrated in a country that doesn’t directly elect its leader. 
A couple of weeks ago Malcolm Turnbull literally had his own side cheering as he launched a fusillade against Bill Shorten in Parliament. It had the appearance of an ad-lib attack that was carefully prepared. 
And it worked, it rallied the troops. 
Expect a similar tactic when Parliament resumes today. 
As for Tony Abbott’s leadership ambitions, the words of Confucius come to mind: "Before you embark on a journey of revenge, dig two graves."
